SENT.plain: A 24-year-old man with left sixth through twelfth cranial nerve palsies and severe, fluctuating, systemic arterial hypertension was found to have a large, vascular, catecholamine-forming glomus jugulare chemodectoma
After his electrolyte imbalance was corrected, left external carotid embolization (using Gelfoam) was carried out
The systemic blood pressure stabilized at around 160/100 mm Hg over the next 12 hours
Ten hours later the hitherto conscious patient developed acute arterial hypotension, lapsed into coma, and died
Autopsy showed tumor infarction, swelling, cerebellar tonsillar herniation, and medullary compression
An unusual complication of glomus tumor embolization is highlighted
The roles of preliminary decompressive surgery and urgent resuscitation by vasopressors are discussed
